title: Population-Level Effectiveness of an Inactivated Whole-Virion COVID-19 Vaccine: A Test Negative Case-Control Study in the Dominican Republic.
author: Pérez-Then; Eddy; Miric; Marija; Qian; Han-Zhu; Chen; Ying Qing; Wang; Yixin; Vallejo; Virginia; Quezada; Wanda; Flaquer; Melissa; Olivo; Juan; Castillo; Jean; García; Natalia; Calderón; Katherine; Cueto; Scarlet; Veras; Bienvenido; Russo; Miguel; Jiménez; Indira; Guzmán; Sorileydi; Garabito; Luz; Evelyn; Colombo; Fátima; Taveras; Dominga; Torres; Dania; Baez; Yunen; Jose; Koenig; Ellen; Pérez; Eladio; López; Oscar; Severino Medina; Fior Estephanie; Xuanyi; Shao; Yiming; Vermund; Sten H

Conclusions:Given the ancestral and [delta]viral variants circulating during this study period, our results suggest that the inactivated [COVID-19 vaccine]offered moderate [protection]against COVID-19-related [hospitalizations]and assisted [ventilation]. This is reassuring given that, as of August 2022, an estimated 2.6 billion inactivated CoronaVac [vaccine]doses had been administered worldwide.
